title: Mercato Vecchio - Firenze. Antonio Fontanesi Reggio Emilia, 1818 - Torino, 1882
dc:description: Executed during his stay in Florence in 1867, the painting presents an unusual subject for Fontanesi. At that time he was working in Banti''s studio and the reflection of the Macchiaioli influence seems to be recognisable in the rendering of the luminous contrast, which translates into the alternation of light and dark that runs across the pavement and outlines the projecting parts of the buildings. On the other hand, urban views of this kind would seem to be connected to the heliographic production to which the artist devoted himself during his years in London.
dc:source: GAM - Torino, 2021
author: Antonio Fontanesi Reggio Emilia, 1818 - Torino, 1882
caption: Mercato Vecchio - Firenze. Antonio Fontanesi Reggio Emilia, 1818 - Torino, 1882

unito_users.reminds_me: Mi ricorda: il mercato del mio paesino

title: Le baiser
author: Francis Picabia Parigi, 1879 - 1953
dc:source: Acquisto presso la Galleria Notizie, Torino, 1969
dc:description:
La cornice dell'opera è stata pensata dall'artista con alcuni segmenti in aggetto lungo il "coronamento" superiore, nonché colorata: sono gli anni in cui Picabia si avvale dell'aiuto di Pierre Legrain. Dopo il periodo, forse più celebre, delle fredde opere sul tema ossessivo della macchina (i quadri dadaisti del "periodo meccanico", iniziati nel 1915), Picabia approda a figure di amanti, ricorrenti, appena accennate e rese con un segno spesso, frutto di una pittura veloce, se non immediata: è il periodo dei "mostri", nella cui serie si inserisce anche Le baiser, di datazione discussa. Irrompono nell'opera un autentico scarto di emozionalità ed un inedita freschezza stilistica. Picabia in questo momento ha già lasciato Parigi per la Costa Azzurra, non prima di essersi risolto a prendere le distanze da André Breton e dal surrealismo.



Riccardo Passoni

unito_users.think_about: momenti pieni di passione, farfalle nello stomaco, perdersi nell'altro
di fare l'ultimo bacio e non si vedranno più.

title: Anticoli sole a picco (Paesaggio di Anticoli)
author: Gigi Chessa, Torino - 1898 - 1935
dc:source: Acquisto presso la Società Promotrice delle Belle Arti, Torino, 1935
dc:description:
Pur non sottraendosi all'autorità di Casorati, Chessa recepisce la pittura di Carena, con cui soggiorna, fra il 1919 ed il 1921, ad Anticoli Corrado. Il ritiro di Anticoli, ricco di informazioni e rapporti di lavoro, di riflessioni sul post - impressionismo e Cezanne in particolare, è importante e fondamentale per la formazione del giovane Chessa. Da tali meditazioni nascono opere come questa, dove la solida struttura formale del gruppo di case, e del paesaggio, è addolcita dalla incidenza della luce che cade dall'alto. 

 

 

Anna Gelli

title: Sponde del Po
author: Demetrio Cosola San Sebastiano Po (TO), 1851-Chivasso (TO), 1895
dc:source: Acquisto presso il Circolo degli Artisti, Torino, 1989.
dc:description:
Il dipinto esposto al circolo degli artisti nel 1881, è stato a volte confuso, per somiglianza tematica e per la presenza sull'opera di un etichetta con la dicitura "Rive del Po", con il quadro di quel title presentato sempre in quella sede nel 1888. Dragone, in occasione della retrospettiva dedicata al pittore a Ivrea e a Torino nel 1951, lo data invece al 1892; dati errati anche nel catalogo del Mallè che indica al 1882 la data di dc:source. In questa teletta l'artista traduce la profondità del paesaggio fluviale in una ricerca di luminosità di ampio respiro resa con una felice gradazione di toni caldi e freddi e con immediatezza di tocco e varietà di pennellata.

Caterina Thellung de Courtelary
Note Blind: (), ,  cm, Inv.Siglato: "D.C...."Iscrizioni sul retro:"N.1 Sponde del Po / del Sig. Demetrio Cosola/Lire 300"; "Rive del Po, opera del 1882  Acquistata dal Municipio".Restauro:" Società Rava s.n.c., Torino, 1989. Recupero della cornice originale: Laboratorio tecnico GCAMC, 1989.

dc:description: The search for the composition of space, the atmosphere of almost metaphysical suspension, the essential colour spread with uniform brushstrokes, highlight the initial influence of Felice Casorati, which Jessie Boswell interprets in a personal and poetic manner. She soon abandoned the influence of the master, approaching the language of the French painters Anna Gelli

title: I Santi Anargiri
author: Albino Galvano,Torino,1907- 1990
dc:source: Acquisto presso la XXV Esposizione Biennale Internazionale d''Arte,Venezia,1950
dc:description: Particular anticipation of the abstract compositions of the fifties, this oil on canvas from the concretist period of the MAC (1949 - 1953) fits between the figurative experiences of naturalistic and cubist expression of the immediate postwar period and the subsequent more taste tests. openly informal and neo - liberty (1955 - 1960) by Galvano. the work is played on geometric rhythmic compositional harmonies, offered by the sharp contrasts of the large whites and blacks and the warm and uniform backgrounds of browns and grays, according to a taste closer to Picasso and Braque than to Kandinsky. nGiorgio Auneddu

title: Piccola composizione (Fantome incantato)
author: Atanasio Soldati, Parma 1896 - 1953
dc:source: Acquisto presso la II Mostra Pittori d'oggi Francia - Italia, Torino 1952
dc:description:
Con la fondazione del Movimento Arte Concreta si assiste ad un coagularsi di forze attorno ad un linguaggio astratto, rinnovato dal confronto in primo luogo con la contemporanea produzione francese, nel tramite di Magnelli. Soldati rielabora creativamente i diversi stimoli culturali in composizioni come la presente, di consumato mestiere e di sapiente equilibrio formale. 

 

Paolo San Martino

La composizione dal profondo taglio orizzontale è costruita intorno alla figura della sinuosa sirena dai lunghi capelli rossi e dalla pelle diafana che cinge il corpo del giovane pescatore che si protende dalla barca. I teschi, visibili in trasparenza sul fondo marino alle spalle della donna,suggeriscono la fine che attende la giovane vittima tra le braccia dell'ammaliatrice Paura, smarrimento, terrore, fascinazione, mistero,  attrazione, paura, favola, rischio, mitologia SIrena, giovane uomo barca

title: Marina
author: Osvaldo Licini, Monte Vidon Corrado (AP), 1894 - 1954
dc:source: Dono di Paolo Licini, Livorno,1969
dc:description:
Negli ultimi anni della sua vita, Licini semplifica il bagaglio di forme che contraddistingue la sua opera e riconduce la tavolozza a tinte prossime a quelle fondamentali, imbastendo le composizizioni su contrasti di complementari. Il presente dipinto si inserisce in questo preciso contesto, denotando un estrema esemplificazione di linee e colori. 

 

Paolo San Martino
caption: Marina

title: Mafai con il gatto
author: Antonietta Raphaël Kovno (Lituania), 1895 c. - Roma, 1975
dc:source: Acquisto della Fondazione Guido ed Ettore De Fornaris dalla famiglia Mafai, Roma, 1990
dc:description: l'ideazione dell'opera risale agli anni del primo soggiorno genovese dell'artista (1939-1943). Il tema è volutamente domestico, antiretorico, e risalta il misterioso atteggiarsi psicologico del ritrattato. l'adozione di un linguaggio sottilmente arcaizzante è di indirizzo ben differente rispetto alla statuaria dell'epoca, e nasce dal ripensamento della lezione di Bourdelle, Maillol, che la Raphaél aveva studiato a fondo a Parigi, al principio degli anni Trenta.

title: Orange Car Crash (5 Deaths 11 Times in Orange) (Orange Disaster)
author: Andy Warhol
dc:source: Acquisto dalla Galleria Sperone, Torino, 1967
dc:description: At the end of the 1950s, Andy Warhol, who had been devoted to painting for a few years in parallel with his activity as an advertising designer, was thunderstruck by the New Dada of Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg and the first Pop vaguities. What attracted him was the procedure chosen by these artists, consisting in the brutal sampling of the most banal and ordinary reality, an operation ideologically opposed to the gestural exuberance of Action Painting. The result is a cold painting, calibrated to the images conveyed by advertising, which necessarily presupposes a rethinking of the role of the artist, who no longer interprets reality, but mechanically repeats it as in a perpetual industrial process, a depersonalisation that reflects that of the individual in modern mass societies. The supermarkets, new temples of consumer culture, fyear their entrance into the museum through the familiar physiognomies of Coca-Cola bottles, Campbell's soup cans and Brillo sponge boxes. In 1963 Warhol finally abandoned the technique of painting for that more congenial to his intentions of serigraphy - more easily replicable and impersonal -, a choice that went hand in hand with the launch of a new series of subjects inspired by death. The first of this cycle entitled Death and disaster is still hand-painted, 129 Die in Jet (Cologne, Museum Ludwig), of 1962, a faithful reproduction of the front page of the "New York Mirror" of 4 June of that year, in which the air disaster in which 129 people perished was documented. This early work was followed by scenes of traffic accidents, suicides, operating theatres, electric chairs, mugshots of criminals, weapons and skulls. The idea behind the artistic operation - the extrapolation of a perceived fragment of reality within a different perimeter of values, the aesthetic one - sustains Orange Car Crash: it picks up a piece of life - albeit a second pass - through yet another photograph of a car accident in 1959, published by United Press International Corporation. By repeatedly replicating an image on canvas, with backgrounds generally as vivid as the colours of advertising language, Warhol induces a sort of visual addiction and consequently a dramatic emptying of the sequence, almost an antidote to the strong emotions of existence.

title: Un Natale! Al Pio Albergo Trivulzio
author: Angelo Morbelli - Alessandria, 1853 - Milano, 1919
dc:source: Acquisto presso la Societa' Promotrice delle Belle Arti, Torino 1912
dc:description: This is the last essay in that very numerous series of interiors of the Ospizio Trivulzio, which began with Giorni Ultimi (Milan, Galleria d'Arte Moderna), 1883. This series is not only a poignant poem of old age for Morbelli, but a pictorial motif in which the artist sees a coherent development of the principle of truth, even after his complete adhesion (from Dawn, '91) to the new Divisionist technique. This technical and scientific supremacy, exemplified by the minute texture of pure colours that animates the painting, by the intense luminescence of the ray of sunlight that strikes the poor benches of the institute, was also judged excessive by Grubicy, leading to a certain critical misfortune for Morbelli.

dc:description: Of the modern genre painting, to which Stratta devoted himself, particularly from the 1890s onwards, treating the restitution of the environment with extreme skill, the painting Arachne, from 1893, is exemplary, in which the interior is rich in references to the orientalism of the end of the 20th century, from the Arab-Hispanic note of the Moorish table that recalls the creations of Carlo Bugatti, to the Japonisme of the rice-paper lamppost and the screen-curtain. The environmental characterisation is aimed at the psychological prominence of the character: The young woman stares voluntarily and questioningly at the spectator, almost in a gesture of defiance, at the centre of an enveloping domestic décor where nature and artifice mingle, while in the diffused light the fabric flight of herons comes to life in a tangle of necks, beaks and wings, almost as if they were the thoughts radiating from the beautiful, enigmatic golden head. Master Fontanesi had in fact written in a letter to his favourite pupil to study life in the open air during the day, dedicating the evening to figure studies, inviting him to refine both expressive polarities of vision: 	he landscape, that is, light, space, the atmosphere and all that is contained in the immensity, that is, the infinite, and the figure, that is, the human soul and all its passions, that is, to make the invisible visible Monica Vinardi
dc:source: GAM - Torino, 2021
caption: Aracne, Carlo Stratta Torino, 1852 – 1936
title: Aracne, Carlo Stratta Torino, 1852 – 1936

dc:description: The work originally appeared as a large rectangle measuring approximately 160x300 cm. In the right-hand part (which was cut down by Morbelli himself and exhibited as an autonomous exemplar in London in 1888, it is now in a private collection) the perspective of the interior widened out over the lifeless bodies of two suicidal lovers. The realistic, literary intentions of an uncovered social chronicle can also be discerned in this conspicuous fragment, sustained by the mute dialogue of inanimate objects rendered with optical fidelity: from the flowers, now withered on the ground, to the top hat negligently placed on the armchair, from the bottles emptied at the lavish banquet that preceded the insane gesture, to the clock on the shelf next to the window through whose shutters the light of the new day shines.

title: Composition T. 50 - 5
author: Hans Hartung Lipsia (Germania), 1904 - Antibes (Francia), 1989
dc:source: Acquisto presso la I Mostra Pittori d'oggi Francia - Italia, Torino, 1951
dc:description: the work is part of an important series of abstract works initiated by the painter in France after World War II. Executed with an essentially gestural and graphic technique of lucid compositional synthesis, and at the same time of extreme spiritual ponderation, the canvas is a good example of the German artist's highest production. Hartung, who always charges the dense texture of his pictorial graphisms with spatial lyricism, expresses himself here with absolute stylistic coherence and chromatic subtlety, vibrant with sensitivity and harmony between sign, gesture and colour. In the composition T. 50-5, the relationship between graphic improvisation and pictorial fabric is substantiated - according to the author's intention - in total experience of reality. On a background prepared to receive them, he draws vibrant, incisive, dry and sharp traces, dense with emotions, already recurring in the Indian ink drawings of his youth. G.A.

title: Via a Parigi
author: Luigi Tibertelli Filippo De PisisFerrara, 1896 - Milano, 1956
dc:source: Acquisto presso la XVIII Esposizione Biennale Internazionale d'Arte , Venezia 1932
dc:description: The work was executed in the Parisian period, when the artist set up his studio at 7 rue Servandoni (1932). The composition, depicting a characteristic view of rue de Cliché, in its fresh and instinctive realisation fits into that extraordinary nucleus of views painted from life amongst the people, as in the example of Rue Cassette (1939, private collection, Florence). The brushstroke here is imbued with that vivid "air of Paris", thick and dense, decisive in the timbres of greens, browns and blacks, and picks up on some motifs of "views" - from shop signs to tree branches (crf. La Senna a Parigi, 1930, private collection, Milan) - according to the impressionistic technique of Monet of La Rue Montorgueil: Fête du 30june (1878). Giorgio Auneddu
Note Blind: Inv. Firmato:"de Pisis"Restauro: Società Rava s.n.c., Torino, 1989

title: Beethoven (Beethoven giovinetto)
author: Giuseppe Grandi Ganna, (VA), 1843-1894
dc:source: Legato di Benedetto Junk, Torino, 1920.
dc:description:
l'opera è la fusione in bronzo del gesso conservato nella Galleria d'Arte Moderna di Milano (Inv. 1259) eseguito per Benedetto Junk ed esposto a Brera nel 1874. A proposito di questo soggetto, si ha notizia dell'esistenza di una variante in gesso già presso la famiglia Troubetzkoy, mentre è nota una replica autografa conservata in una collezione privata emiliana. Il busto del giovane musicista, dall'originalissimo e dinamico taglio compositivo che include anche il braccio e la mano destra, quest'ultima cardine solo apparentemente secondario dell'opera, bene testimonia delle possibilità di resa pittorica raggiunte dalla ricerca plastica di Grandi a questa data.

Alfonzo Panzetta
Note Blind: (), ,  cm, Inv. Iscrizioni: "BEETHOVEN"Restauro: Ines Minina Pignoni, Torino, 1992

title: Contadini al sole
author: Felice Carena Cumiana (TO), 1879 - Venezia , 1966
dc:source: Acquisto presso la Società Promotrice delle Belle Arti, Torino, 1919
dc:description: The knowledge of post-impressionist painting, through direct vision of the works and through the stories of his friend and art critic Emilio Cecchi, gives a fundamental turning point to the figurative path of Carena, who progressively investigates the different developments of impressionism, while maintaining completely original formal and chromatic characteristics. The painting marks the artist's return to painting after the tragic interruption of the war and is a document of his infatuation with Gauguin, whose exotic world is lowered into the rural and primitive reality of Anticoli Corrado, a small town in Lazio that became, in the years of conflict , a real community of artists. Laura d'Agostino

title: 03 - F
author: Giorgio Nelva, Lanzo (TO), 1940
dc:source: Dono dell'artista, Torino, 1969
dc:description:
Realizzata durante il periodo di attività del Gruppo Sperimentale d'Arte di Torino (1963 - 1965), l'opera documenta l'interesse dell'author per i meccanismi della percezione visiva e per il rapporto tra l'arte e la società tecnologica. Si tratta della sovrapposizione di un doppio reticolo geometrico, giocata sul contrasto del bianco e del nero e sullo sfruttamento della trasparenza del plexiglas. Le diverse possibilità di configurazione della struttura visiva possono realizzarsi solo attraverso l'intervento del riguardante. 

 

Maria Teresa Roberto

title: Il torrente d'inverno
author: Giuseppe Bozzalla Biella, 1874 - Pollone (VC), 1958
dc:source: Acquisto presso la Società Promotrice delle Belle Arti, Torino, 1910
dc:description: The sinuous profile of the banks and trunks adds to the subtle charm of the landscape, reflecting the artist's adherence to the Secessionist art nouveau taste. The optical truth of the foreground, evidenced by the iridescence of the snow cover and the livid transparencies of the water, creates a singular contrast with the deliberately undefined landscape and cloudy sky. Virginia Bertone

title: La femme de Claude (l'adultera)
author: Francesco Mosso Torino, 1848 - Rivalta (TO), 1877
dc:source: Acquisto presso la Societa'; Promotrice delle Belle Arti, Torino, 1877
dc:description: The painting was conceived, as Calderini writes, in 1874, in a room of the Turin Prefecture, where the painter "saw a beautiful ray of sunlight vibrate in a song, on an antique sofa, covered in light-coloured satin". Executed in Rome, under the influence of his painter friend Cesare Maccari, the large painting depicting an "honour killing camouflaged under the title La femme ce Claude" was sent to Turin to the 1877 Promotrice exhibition where it provoked discussion and criticism. Mosso adapts the composition and theatricality of the academic painting to a theme of modern realism rendered with crude chronicle accents. The undeniable pictorial quality adds tones of soft eroticism to the scene. Catherine Thellung

title: La pittrice
author: Lorenzo Delleani Pollone (VC), 1840-Torino, 1908
dc:source: Legato di Ettore De Fornaris, Torino, 1978.
dc:description:
Il dipinto, che ritrae una delle allieve dell'artista, costituisce un significativo omaggio alla pittura en plein air, verso la quale Delleani si sente ormai sospinto con sempre maggiore urgenza. In questa tavoletta una delle prime realizzate nel formato 37x25 a cui l'artista rimarrà legato per anni, sono già presenti le predilette gamme cromatiche che vyear dai gialli alle infinite sfumature di verdi che risalgono verso un cielo cenerino, nonchè i rapporti armonici tra la composizione "geometrizzante" del paesaggio e le linee più morbide e indefinite delle figure.

Antonella Casassa
Note Blind: 1881, olio su tavola, 37,2x25,5 cm, Inv. P/1955Firmato e datato: Delleani 13.9.81"Iscrizioni sul retro: "Collezione Ludovico Cartotti

title: Strada laterale
author: Atanasio Soldati, Parma 1896 - 1953
dc:source: Legato di Maria Cantoni Soldati, Milano,1986
dc:description:
Dopo la stagione degli anni Trenta si apre per Soldati una nuova fase di ricerca, tesa all'incirca dal 1941al 1947, nella quale riaffiora un indirizzo metafisico già esplorato all'inizio del quarto decennio. In questa nuova stagione di lavoro l'attenzione alla metafisica di Carrà e Morandi si coniuga con una particolare suggestione determinata dalla pittura di Klee, di cui Soldati contribuisce peraltro a favorire la ricezione nel contesto artistico italiano dell'immediato dopoguerra. Come osserva Nello Ponente, in "Strada Laterale " si può individuare il "superamento dell'antitesi tra figurativo e astratto" caratterizzante la seconda stagione metafisica soldatiana. La superficie pittorica si frantuma in un caleidoscopico gioco di forme multicolori nitidi e precise, immerse in una sospesa dimensione atemporale , che dyear vita a una metafisica scenografia di fronte alla quale lo sguardo dello spettatore rimbalza dal primo piano al fondo, o si perde negli improvvisi e improbabili affondi prospettici. Il colore puro, steso in campiture piatte, evita ogni effetto di vibrazione atmosferica, ogni seduzione tonale, facendosi assoluto e immateriale. 

 

 

Lara Conte

unito_users.think_about: percorsi della vita, passato e presente che si intrecciano in un futuro che a volte sembra incerto, altre volte più sicuro.

title: L'edera
author: Tranquillo Cremona Pavia, 1837 - Milano, 1878
dc:source: Legato di Benedetto Junck, Torino, 1920
dc:description: The work, the last of Cremona's works, was commissioned from the painter by Benedetto Junck and elaborated in the Scapigliatura milieu. The models are the musician Alfredo Catalani and Lisetta Cagnoli, Cremona''s sister-in-law. The Ivy - by far one of the most famous paintings of the 19th century - once again condenses the characteristic features of the painter''s art, which softens reality with the typical vaporous brushstroke, without repentance, and immerses it in that well-known hazy atmosphere that one wants to trace back to the blurred but vigorous impastositions of Piccio. This highly fortunate pictorial formula was indeed immediately criticised by his contemporaries (as early as The Two Cousins, 1871, Rome, Galleria Nazionale d''Arte Moderna), who saw Cremona''s experimentation as a loophole to avoid the confrontation with reality - considered inevitable and necessary.

unito_users.makes_me_feel: Riluttanza, passione, speranza, desiderio, tensione, avvolgente

title: I funerali di Tiziano
caption: I Funerali di Tiziano - Enrico Gamba Torino, 1818 - 1887
author: Enrico Gamba Torino, 1818 - 1887
dc:source: Dono del Re Umberto I, 1899
dc:description: The new attitude of European Romantic culture towards the past is reflected in the large number of paintings devoted to the life and work of earlier artists up to the first half of the 19th century. It is in this context that Gamba's painting should be placed, inspired by Ridolfi's Le meraviglie dell'arte ovvero le Vite degli illustri pittori veneti (1646-1648), where it is recounted, albeit without historical foundation, how the Venetian Republic exceptionally allowed the solemn funeral of Titian to take place during the plague of 1576, as a sign of honour to the artist. The result of a three-year elaboration (preparatory drawings at the Galleria Civica in Turin), the painting, which, through the exaltation of a great Italian, also takes on a clear patriotic significance, was exhibited at the Promotrice in Turin in 1856, where it was bought by King Vittorio Emanuele II. Its success earned the artist the chair of drawing at the Accademia Albertina in Turin.

title: Dans mon pays
author: Marc Chagall - Vitebsk (Russia), 1887 - Vence (Francia), 1985
materialAndTechnique: Guazzo e tempera su carta applicata su tela
dc:source: Acquisto presso la XXII Esposizione Biennale Internazionale d'Arte,Venezia, 1948
dc:description: The work was created in Mexico during the artist's American sojourn (1941 - 1943). The Russian element evoked in this intense painting is poetically present in the fantastic solution of the landscape, which is the one dear and familiar to the artist's childhood in Vitebsk: old wooden dachas, narrow streets with picket fences, shop signs, young lovers, domestic animals, all united in a "supernatural" world - according to Apollinaire's definition - that is in any case fantastic and surreal of idyllic stillness. The bright sumptuousness of the blue colour, with the dense white light of the moon placed in the centre, on the snow, under the horse's belly, achieves here a magical depth and resonance, acquiring a strong inner suggestiveness that communicates, in the transfiguration of the dream, restlessness and sadness, immersed as it is in the yearning and melancholic tenderness of memory. Giorgio Auneddu

title: Ragazza con scodella (Interno)  (Mattino)
author: Felice Casorati Novara, 1883 - Torino, 1963
caption: Ragazza con scodella (Interno)  (Mattino) - curator's notes
dc:source: Acquisto dal rag. Benedetto Fiore, Torino, 1959
dc:description: Scena d'interno.Casorati pone in primo piano una figura femminile molto stilizzata  ridotta all'essenziale, siede su un cubo all'interno di una stanza spoglia senza arredi se non una cassa  un recipiente vuoti, tiene tra le mani una scodella anch'essa vuota, la struttura del quadro è fortemente geometrica con  una fuga prospetticva esasperata.   Inquietudine, allienazione, solitudine, angoscia, malinconia, rassegnazione., irreale, essenziale   Figura femminile     L'artista ricorre all'uso della geometria e delle forme essenziali per trasmettere freddezza e irrealtà, tutti gli oggetti sono  vuoti ad indicare assenza e privazione. i vestiti sono semplici, lineari così come la figura stessa che  tiene gli occhi chiusi  come se si estraniasse.ragazza seduta    Casorati pone in primo piano una figura livida, assente, un volume inserito entro una fuga prospettica fortemente allungata, in una luce irreale che disegna misteriose ombre sul pavimento in cotto: a sottolineare quasi il disagio e la desolazione in cui vive la ragazza, che emblematicamente tiene tra le mani una scodella vuota. I contorni chiusi dei pochi oggetti segnano pause spaziali, connotano il silenzio della scena. E' uno dei più bei dipinti dell'avvio torinese di Casorati, di controllata ma intensa trasformazione stilistica dopo la stagione secessionista.    giovinezza, malinconia, straniamento, luce, mattino giovane donna   scodella

title: Le allieve
author: Lorenzo Delleani Pollone (VC), 1840-Torino, 1908
dc:source: Legato di Ettore De Fonaris, Torino, 1978
dc:description: The subject of the pupils painting en plein air, already treated in the work of 13.9.1881 (Inv. P/1955), returns in this panel, once again immersed in the luminous atmosphere of September. Here, the group of five figures, with its red and white patches of colour and fragmented occupation of space, provides the right counterpoint to the green tones of the slope and the sobriety of line of the landscape to which the three bare trees on the right dyear essential depth. Antonella Casassa

title: La ragazza rossa (Testa di donna dai capelli rossi)
subject: La ragazza rossa
author: Amedeo Modigliani Livorno, 1884 - Parigi, 1920
dc:source: Dono del Comitato Torino 61, Torino, 1962
dc:description: In his work as a sculptor first and then as a painter, Modigliani always expressed his passion for the figure without hesitation, never renouncing to portray, throughout his short life, friends, poets, art dealers, occasional models. With exceptional ease and spontaneity, he simultaneously translated the physiognomy of a face, the expression of the gaze, the state of mind, ignoring the laws of perspective and chiaroscuro. His gallery of portraits, never painted from memory but always with a model, has the immediacy and truth of a very personal diary, because the freedom of expression is always authentic and the execution fast, entrusted to the drawing, as subtle as a pencil point, but sharp and constructive.

title: Autoritratto in forma di gufo
author: Alberto Savinio
materialAndTechnique: tempera e cartoncino su carta applicata su compensato
dc:source: Acquisto dal rag. Benedetto Fiore, Torino, 1959
dc:description: Hybrid figures composed of human bodies and animal heads depicted in bourgeois clothing appear in Savinio''s iconographic production from 1930 onwards. These portraits are understood as character studies, where the real portrait is the revelation of the hidden man. Stimulated by Weininger ´on the physical and psychic analogies between men and animals´, this way of understanding the figure is part of an ideal gallery of family portraits among which the earliest examples are: The Faithful Bride (1929; private coll.) and The Return of the Prodigal Son (1931-1932; private coll.). Characterised by a somewhat "phantasmic" realism, close to the bewildering Surrealist representation (Ernst), this Self-Portrait in the Form of an Owl is executed in a lean, opaque tone of reddish browns and greys, with dry white highlights on the head and on the large gnarled hand resting on the waistcoat. Always in Savinio''s poetics, the subject is intended as a sort of self-revelation, a laying bare of the character in his physical and psychological reality.

title: Il Pescatorello
author: Vincenzo Gemito Napoli, 1852-1929
dc:source: Legato di Ettore De Fornaris, Torino, 1978.
dc:description: The theme, dear to Gemito''s heart, of the young fisherman balancing precariously on a rock is here elegantly treated with collected and closed forms. Numerous replicas and variants are known of the work, probably executed in 1876 on commission from the prefect Diomede Marvasi, some of which are autograph, others (and they are the vast majority) commissioned by the family after the artist''s death. In the current state of knowledge, this makes it impossible to date this specimen accurately. The Galleria d''Arte Moderna in Milan owns a bronze and a wax of this subject, while another wax is kept in the Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Moderna in Rome. Alfonzo Panzetta

title: La primavera
author: Mario Sturani Ancona, 1906 - Torino, 1978
dc:source: Dono della famiglia Sturani alla Fondazione Guido ed Ettore De Fornaris, Torino 1990
dc:description: The two vases belong to the Four Seasons cycle. In the complete series purchased in 1932 in Paris also by Josephine Baker, a mythical symbol, in those years, of distant countries, Sturani distinguishes himself not only for his chromatic vivacity and extraordinary imagination in dealing with the theme, but also for his unusual ability in adapting the human image. The real datum is transfigured in a freely fantastic sense, as in the case of the Seasons, or caricatured, as in the Vase-masks where heads and faces are adapted to the silhouette of the vases.
Note Blind: cmmarca: Lenci MADE IN ITALY 7 XIII

title: Maternità
author: Arturo Martini Treviso, 1889 - Milano, 1947
dc:source: Dono del prof. Lionello Venturi, Torino, 1932
dc:description: In this work presented at the I Quadriennale in Rome, Martini aggregates the volumes of children clinging to their mother''s body according to an ascending rhythm. The theme of motherhood is rendered through the expressiveness of gestures, in the reference to the image of a tree bearing its fruit. Carved into a trunk that reveals its arboreal consistency in the base, the plastic form emerges as an embossment, but in some places - for example in the woman''s left hand - it is suggested in the negative. In the article that Lionello Venturi dedicated to Martini in "l''Arte" (VI(1930), p. 577), the work, that he had wanted in his collection, was signalled as a masterpiece, through a reading conducted in the name of the taste for primitives: "Give that group the title of Carita': and you will make it a tragic Caryatid for a Romanesque cathedral." Maria Teresa Roberto

title: La Signora di Monza col ritratto dell'amante Egidio. a) La monaca di Monza; b) l''amante Egidio.
author: Mose' Bianchi Monza (MI), 1840- 1904
dc:source: Acquisto presso la Societa' promotrice di Belle Arti, Torino, 1867
dc:description: The two paintings - previously separate - are now exhibited in a diptych within the original frame. The iconography - not indifferent to the implied social character of the subject - is part of that conspicuous series of Manzonian subjects that inform numerous works of historical Romanticism. Bianchi re-proposes several versions of Gertrude in public exhibitions, following the first version executed in 1865 (Monza, Musei Civici). The Turin exemplar differs - as well as for the eccentric inclusion of the "wicked Egidio", a gloomy self-portrait of the young painter - for a drier and at times poorer use of colour, for a subtle and highly refined material torment that mitigates the academic finesse of the paintings.

title: Capanni sul mare
author: Carlo Carra' Quargnento (AL), 1881 - Milano, 1966
materialAndTechnique: olio su tela applicata su cartone
dc:source: Acquisto presso la XVI Esposizione Internazionale d'Arte, Venezia, 1928
dc:description:
Il dipinto si collega alla svolta paesaggistica degli anni Venti di Carrà, bilanciata tra osservazione ed astrazione. I contrasti sordi dei colori - blu mare all'orizzonte, i bianchi sporchi ed i rossi mattone dei capanni - concorrono nel definire forme essenziali e riconoscibili; linee orizzontali e verticali determinano una scansione spaziale in cui risaltano infatti i semplici solidi delle architetture. l'artista in questi anni parla di "suprema armonia dei volumi", quindi della "profonda poesia di un insieme di forma ben costruite" (Neoclassicismo e realismo, "l'ambrosiano", 1.8.1925).

Riccardo Passoni

title: Angles
author: Jean Fautrier - Parigi,1898 - Chatenay - Malabry 1964
materialAndTechnique: Olio su carta applicata su tela
dc:source: Purchase of the Fondazione per l''Arte Moderna e Contemporanea CRT from the Zonca & Zonca Gallery,Milan,2008
dc:description: Leading figure and progenitor of the more material trend of European Informal art, which coalesced around the critic Michel Tapi in the early 1950s, Jean Fautrier gave form and substance to the horrors of war - experienced first-hand during the German occupation in France - with the "Otages", a series of works composed of about thirty pieces, created between 1942 and 1945, and exhibited almost entirely at the Drouin gallery in Paris. In these works, which translated both the dramatic situation of the historical contingency of the conflict and the more general situation of the condition of man in the twentieth century, humanity, in the grip of the most ferocious instincts, lost its recognisability through physiognomic descriptiveness and took on the violated and lacerated physicality of formless matter, similar to the shreds of flesh of a massacred body. A material bearing the deep stigmata of suffering and torment; just as a slow torture must have seemed to be the work with which the artist obtained his images from the paper laid out on the table, amalgamating with spatulas the white of Spain and glue, finished with a light layer of colouring oils. These disfigured faces, deprived of any human connotation, paved the way for what became his characteristic expressive style, in which the harsh and brutal material always plays a decisive role, although with time the chromatic structure of his works tends to lighten and lose the more dramatic connotations of his early works. This process of lightening can be seen in "Angles", where the lumpy, relief-like paste is detached from the lean background like a bas-relief, arranged in a grid-like texture that reveals a different volition of spatial geometry.

title: Suonatore di chitarra (Commedia)
author: Felice Casorati, Novara 1883 - Torino 1963
dc:source: Dono di Francesco Casorati alla Fondazione Guido ed Ettore De Fornaris , Torino, 1986
dc:description: An identical accordion player with an Etruscan smile decorated the proscenium of the Gualino theatre in Via Galliari in Turin; an accordion player (Tragedy) was his counterpart. The theatre, commissioned by Gualino from Casorati - who availed himself of the architect Alberto Sartoris in the design - was started in 1923 and inaugurated on 27 April 1925. The sculptures were in grey: the different patination of the Suonatore di chitarra by GCAMC suggests that our work is actually a cast of the statue of the theatre (which has been lost), which was presented with its pendant at the Venice Biennale in 1928, and probably executed by Casorati in that year. Riccardo Passoni

title: Miracolo (Olocausto)
author: Marino (Marino Marini)
dc:source: Acquisto dall''artista, Milano, 1965
dc:description: After the tragic years of the Second World War, the feeling of life in Marino becomes more and more gloomy and his work is charged with a profound anguish: the Knights, mythical figures and metaphor of the human condition, lose the olimetic equilibrium of the previous versions and they gasp desperately until they fall off their soaring steeds. This new dramatic cycle begins in 1943, when the artist is forced to retire to Switzerland, and takes the name of Miracles. Throughout the 1950s, the tragic collapses followed one another in a crescendo of tearing tension: the horse is on the ground and the rider no longer struggles, but collapses lifelessly, an apocalyptic image of the ruin that had overwhelmed the European world with no more hope. Laura d''Agostino

title: (Der) Matrose Fritz Mfaller aus Pieschen
author: Otto Dix Untemhaus (Germania), 1891 - Hemmenhofen (Germania), 1969
materialAndTechnique: tecnica mista, tempera e velatura ad olio su carta intelata con cornice originale dell'author
dc:source: Acquisto presso la Galleria Klihm, Monaco, 1967
dc:description: This important work belongs to Dix''s youthful period, and is only a few months before the real turning point of his style, which was inclined towards the new realist orientation that would occur after 1920. The compositional sense of the painting is influenced by the unique intersection of Dadaism, Cubism and Futurism. Significant thematic and formal similarities with this work are found in works such as: Self-portrait in the guise of a target, 1915 (Otto Dix Stiftung, Schaffhausen) and, above all, Súdlicher Matrose, 1923 (ibid.), which differs in the figure of the sailor only in the addition of the pipe in his mouth, and Hafenszene (Port Scene), 1922 (private coll. private collection), close not only in iconographic interpretation, but also in the clear and brilliant colours with dominant blue and green tones.

title: Ritorno alla stalla (La ritirata)
author: Carlo Pittara, 1835 o 1836 - Rivara Canavese (TO), 1891
dc:source: Acquisto presso la Società Promotrice di Belle Arti, Torino, 1866
dc:description: Skilfully playing on grey-brown tones to render the effect of the rain and on horizontal perspective cuts, interrupted by the verticality of the two shepherds with their brightly coloured umbrellas, the painting captures as if in a snapshot the return of the sheep to the fold. As A. Griseri in 1967: "Before the sheep of Pellizza and Segantini, these are the most beloved animals to emerge from nineteenth-century painting, all the more moved than those of Palizzi". Trained as an animalist, Pittara was known and respected by his contemporaries precisely for this aspect of his production. But his insistence on the humble world of pastoralism was disliked by some commentators. Accepted by officialdom for his respect of the traditional pictorial language, Pittara was judged by Stella (Turin, 1893, p. 276) as alien to "certain boldness" and "brutality" of Courbet''s style.
Note Blind: Inv. Firmato: "C. Pittara"Restauro: Nicola Restauri s.r.l. Aramengo (AT), 1982-Recupero della cornice originale: Laboratorio tecnico GCAMC, 1992

title: Pugilatore - The Boxer
author: Francesco Messina Linguaglossa (CT), 1900 - Milano, 1995
dc:source: Acquisto presso la XVII Esposizione Internazionale d''Arte, Venezia, 1930
dc:description: At the centre of Messina styear''s entirely figurative research is man and the incredible truth of his body: as perfection and harmony, exaltation, problem and physical limit, but nevertheless vehicle and emblem of every experience. His figures hyear the steadiness and balance of classical statuary, but the interpretation adheres acutely to reality and the formal reading communicates what has already happened, or is about to happen, in a sort of psychological investigation of the muscles. In the Boxer, a theme of which there are some variants, everything expresses the moment that follows the great effort: the legs still contracted, the shoulders relaxed forward, the face panting. The extraordinary technique underlying the formal result reflects Messina''s commitment to being a craftsman before being an artist, and to knowing all the materials and working methods.

title: Dopo il duello
author: Antonio Mancini - Roma, 1852 - 1935
dc:source: Acquisto da Eugenio Ventura, Torino, 1935
dc:description: AElegantly bourgeois clothes clothe in this painting the Neapolitan model who appears as a scugnizzo and acrobat in numerous paintings by the artist. In this youthful work, the situation is set in a moment of theatrical drama in which the anguish manifested in the boy''s face and the looming shadow on the left increase the mystery of the subject''s interpretation, strained between reality and fiction. The colours play on the suspended atmosphere, from the yellow-orange of the back wall on which the shadows produced by the black of the dress rise, to the contrast of the dazzling white of the shirt in the foreground. Elisabetta Ballaira
